summary: Faramir deserves tons of love... But from who? I love the idea of Faramir with Sansa, but something in my mind keeps suggesting...

Faramir deserves tons of love… But from who?

I love the idea of Faramir with Sansa, but something in my mind keeps suggesting Margaery… What do you all think?

summary: Bittersweet - Chapter 19 - A letter from the vale
title: Bittersweet - Chapter 19 - A letter from the vale
body:
Another chapter of my slowburn…. Mostly setting up for the next greater arc. The vale might look like a diversion, but it is necessary for a latter plot point…. Also on AO3.

 “Dear Sansa, I hope this letter finds you and your children well. I have written several times already, but with the whole of Westeros in the grip of Winter, the ravens might not have reached you. The latest message I received from you was the news about the Riverlands. I was glad to hear that Hoster Tully has reached Winterfell. I am convinced that you will be an excellent warden for him. I suspect that you have written since, but no raven reached us here in the Vale.

My health has not been the best of late, although I try to keep quiet about it. The medicine I take is highly recommended by my new Maester Rhyswont, so I still have hope that my health improves. My old Maester Colemon has died of a sudden fever and my conditions has worsened since that. With the war in the South decided for Daenerys, my knights worry that we will have to face another threat from the South soon. Harold Hardyng, my beloved and trusted heir, is sceptical about your need for our knights. Even though several men have told him about the abominations they met north of the Wall, he refuses to believe. Therefore, I send him to Winterfell together with Maester Rhyswont, who is also a sceptic. I want him to judge the situation on his own. If anything happens to me I want my heir to honour our alliance. This is the fourth message I’ve sent to you and it might be, that by the time it reaches you, Harold is already close to Winterfell. Robin Arryn, Warden of the East.”

Jon read it out loud. When he had received the letter his first thought was that Sansa would help him steering through the troubled waters. Jon had the feeling that there was more to this letter than met the eye. Sansa knew her cousin. It was only when he had finished reading out the letter loudly and asked Sansa what it all meant that he realised that Sansa shook her head in an almost inperceptible way.

“We’d better discuss this in the council,” Sansa said at the same time as Gilly exclaimed loudly: “Maester Rhyswont!”

Jon was distracted by Gilly’s face which was a grimace of distaste.

“What about Maester Rhyswont?” he asked.

Gilly combed Podrick’s hair with determination which earned her a high-pitched yelp, when the comb did not run through his hair smoothly.

“Maester Rhyswont is a very good maester, but he treats women like they are all dumbwits. He was one of the few who would protest against me sitting quietly in the back of the classes to listen.” Gilly grumbled.

“He is a good healer though.”, she admitted. “He left shortly before we made our way North.”.

“If he is a good healer why does Lord Robin send him North though?”, Sansa mused, voicing one of the oddities of the letter. There was a frown on her forehead.

“And who sent the raven from the Vale, if he was already on his way here?” Jon asked.

“Robin might have someone at hand who is capable to tend the ravens.” Sansa stretched out her hand and Jon handed her the letter.

“This letter is from Robin,” she confirmed, fingering Robin’s signature.

“What do you make of it?” Jon wanted to know.

Sansa sighed. “We really should discuss this in council,” she chided him, but relented when she saw his face. His anxiousness which had nothing to do with Maester Rhyswont or Lord Robin’s health must have been visible on his face.

“It is odd, that Robin mentions the new medicine. I would say, that he suspects that it is not good for his health at all and he wants the Maester away to test this.” Sansa looked at the nitcomb absentmindedly.

“I do not like this,” she admitted. “He calls this Harold his ‘beleoved and trusted’ heir. Why trust him, if he is sceptic about the White Walkers and the conditions of our alliance.”

The alliance. The alliance he wants honoured. Jon felt a cold fear clutch at his heart. He knew how alliances were forged and he did not like it. Not at all. Harold comes as a suitor for Sansa’s hand. He looked down at his hand that shook with anger at the thought and tried to get his temper in hand. Sansa will not leave Winterfell, she’ll stay here with me. He wished he could feel secure about this. What will she do, if this Harold sets conditions for the troops from the Vale. What if Robin dies? Jon had never met Sansa’s cousin and Sansa had told him that the sickly Robin was not easy to deal with, but he was fond of his cousin and Jon knew that it was only due to this fondness that Robin had refrained from revenging Littlefinger’s death. He had been a good ally over three years, and the Vale had bled in the continuous war against the Walkers like the North had.

Sansa seemed to feel Jon’s eyes on her and tried a reassuring smile.

“I do think he wants us to assess this Maester Rhyswont and his heir. It is a prudent move. Let the sceptic learn something about our war, remove the Maester in case he is behind his worsened health, and remove his heir who might be overly ambitions. If I read this letter right, Robin had to appease a hostile fraction at his court.” She paused.

“It also means he trust us to convince that fraction and help him.” She looked at the comb in her hands again and then raised her face to him. Her blue eyes met his.

“Apparently he did learn some things while he was Littlefinger’s ward”, Jon tried to distract some of the tension with a joke.

The corner of Sansa’s mouth only quirked lightly.

“So many ravens lost worries me,” Sansa said. “I’ve written twice while you were at the wall. It could be an accident of course.”

She concentrated on her comb again. She’s avoiding looking at me. Jon’s heart felt like a lump in his chest. He had hoped that he was mistaken about the message of the last sentence.

There was an uncomfortable silence. Jon could feel the blood rushing in his ears. I should not have come, I should have waited.

“We should decide on what our answer will be, if that Harold wants to marry me.” Sansa said in an almost whisper. She looked up again and this time she held Jon’s gaze.

His heart made an odd jump. Our answer. He felt as if Sansa and he were the only people in the room. He did not see any of the others in the room, just Sansa.

“We cannot outright deny him,” Jon answered. “Not before he has pledged to fight with us against the Walkers.” I could always just chop off his head. That dark thought came unbidden and Jon shuddered involuntarily.

“No, but we can detain him. It might mean that you’ll have to go to the Wall again to show him proof.”

Jon felt blood rush in his face. It filled him with grim satisfaction that there was no question for Sansa, that she would not want to marry this Harold, but he also realised that he might have given away some of his feelings to others. Again. I must be more careful.

“I would like to avoid that. With the gods staying silent, I feel there is great danger here in Winterfell. ‘Stay alert’ they said. No order about going North.” ‘Stay alert. Stay steadfast’. Jon did not want to leave again.

“Yes, that is worrying. I really wish they had been clearer about that.” Sansa agreed.

Suddenly she laughed.

“The best way to detain him would probably be to avoid that he even asks the question,” she finally said, when she had contained her mirth.

“You just have to pretend that you don’t understand his question at all. Keep yourself busy, keep bannermen around you. And I’ll be very carefuly that he doesn’t catch me alone either.”

Her eyes glinted with amusement.

“Maybe it was a good idea, that you brought this here. I’m sure we can spread the word, that people have to keep us busy.”

Jon smiled. The scheme did appeal to him, but it would mean less time alone with Sansa. Not that they had had much of this lately. I guess, if I want some time alone, I have to catch nits again.

“I still would like to have an edge. I don’t trust this Harold already. If you read Robin’s letter right, he might be very dangerous in his ambition.”

Jon let his eyes wander around the room, fully taking in the persons in the room for the first time.

His gaze went back to Lady Alys. He narrowed his eyes. The Gods told me that she is like my sister. I should trust her.

“Lady Alys, there is a great opportunity to prove your loyalty” he addressed her.

Alys looked up, her face curious in a way that did remind him of his sister Arya and shortly made his heart ache.

“You know how to fight, but you have not yet a reputation like Lady Brienne has.” Alys made a face as if she had an idea what Jon was about to ask.

“Have you written to Robin about Alys?” Jon asked Sansa. She shook her head.

“You could be the new court lady of Lady Sansa, dagger hidden in your dress, just in case. It would comfort me to know that somebody is around Lady Sansa, in case this Harold forgets himself.”

Alys’ face fell. “A dress?”, she exclaimed, misery plain on her face.

Jon grinned. “A dress. You would only need to do this for as long as this Harold Hardyng is here.” He couldn’t help himself. His voice already betrayed his dislike for a man he had never met.

“Jon,” Sansa interrupted him. “You cannot possibly order Lady Alys to do that. It’s clear she doesn’t like dresses.”

Alys turned her face to Sansa.

“I’ll do it,” she said. “I’ll wear bloody dresses and prevent that man to get you alone.”

That took Sansa by surprise, Jon could see that.

“Only under one condition, though,” Alys added.

“Which would be?”, Sansa asked.

Alys gave her a mischievous grin that made her look like a younger girl.

“If these men from the Vale bring nits and lice to Winterfell again I want you to allow me to dump them from the castle battlements and drive them out of Winterfell.”

“I’ll do the dumping with you.”

Jon was distracted by Gilly’s face which was a grimace of distaste.

“What about Maester Rhyswont?” he asked.

Gilly combed Podrick’s hair with determination which earned her a high-pitched yelp, when the comb did not run through his hair smoothly.

“Maester Rhyswont is a very good maester, but he treats women like they are all dumbwits. He was one of the few who would protest against me sitting quietly in the back of the classes to listen.” Gilly grumbled.

“He is a good healer though.”, she admitted. “He left shortly before we made our way North.”.

“If he is a good healer why does Lord Robin send him North though?”, Sansa mused, voicing one of the oddities of the letter. There was a frown on her forehead.

“And who sent the raven from the Vale, if he was already on his way here?” Jon asked.

“Robin might have someone at hand who is capable to tend the ravens.” Sansa stretched out her hand and Jon handed her the letter.

“This letter is from Robin,” she confirmed, fingering Robin’s signature.

“What do you make of it?” Jon wanted to know.

Sansa sighed. “We really should discuss this in council,” she chided him, but relented when she saw his face. His anxiousness which had nothing to do with Maester Rhyswont or Lord Robin’s health must have been visible on his face.

“It is odd, that Robin mentions the new medicine. I would say, that he suspects that it is not good for his health at all and he wants the Maester away to test this.” Sansa looked at the nitcomb absentmindedly.

“I do not like this,” she admitted. “He calls this Harold his ‘beleoved and trusted’ heir. Why trust him, if he is sceptic about the White Walkers and the conditions of our alliance.”

The alliance. The alliance he wants honoured. Jon felt a cold fear clutch at his heart. He knew how alliances were forged and he did not like it. Not at all. Harold comes as a suitor for Sansa’s hand. He looked down at his hand that shook with anger at the thought and tried to get his temper in hand. Sansa will not leave Winterfell, she’ll stay here with me. He wished he could feel secure about this. What will she do, if this Harold sets conditions for the troops from the Vale. What if Robin dies? Jon had never met Sansa’s cousin and Sansa had told him that the sickly Robin was not easy to deal with, but he was fond of his cousin and Jon knew that it was only due to this fondness that Robin had refrained from revenging Littlefinger’s death. He had been a good ally over three years, and the Vale had bled in the continuous war against the Walkers like the North had.

Sansa seemed to feel Jon’s eyes on her and tried a reassuring smile.

“I do think he wants us to assess this Maester Rhyswont and his heir. It is a prudent move. Let the sceptic learn something about our war, remove the Maester in case he is behind his worsened health, and remove his heir who might be overly ambitions. If I read this letter right, Robin had to appease a hostile fraction at his court.” She paused.

“It also means he trust us to convince that fraction and help him.” She looked at the comb in her hands again and then raised her face to him. Her blue eyes met his.

“Apparently he did learn some things while he was Littlefinger’s ward”, Jon tried to distract some of the tension with a joke.

The corner of Sansa’s mouth only quirked lightly.

“So many ravens lost worries me,” Sansa said. “I’ve written twice while you were at the wall. It could be an accident of course.”

She concentrated on her comb again. She’s avoiding looking at me. Jon’s heart felt like a lump in his chest. He had hoped that he was mistaken about the message of the last sentence.

There was an uncomfortable silence. Jon could feel the blood rushing in his ears. I should not have come, I should have waited.

“We should decide on what our answer will be, if that Harold wants to marry me.” Sansa said in an almost whisper. She looked up again and this time she held Jon’s gaze.

His heart made an odd jump. Our answer. He felt as if Sansa and he were the only people in the room. He did not see any of the others in the room, just Sansa.

“We cannot outright deny him,” Jon answered. “Not before he has pledged to fight with us against the Walkers.” I could always just chop off his head. That dark thought came unbidden and Jon shuddered involuntarily.

“No, but we can detain him. It might mean that you’ll have to go to the Wall again to show him proof.”

Jon felt blood rush in his face. It filled him with grim satisfaction that there was no question for Sansa, that she would not want to marry this Harold, but he also realised that he might have given away some of his feelings to others. Again. I must be more careful.

“I would like to avoid that. With the gods staying silent, I feel there is great danger here in Winterfell. ‘Stay alert’ they said. No order about going North.” ‘Stay alert. Stay steadfast’. Jon did not want to leave again.

“Yes, that is worrying. I really wish they had been clearer about that.” Sansa agreed.

Suddenly she laughed.

“The best way to detain him would probably be to avoid that he even asks the question,” she finally said, when she had contained her mirth.

“You just have to pretend that you don’t understand his question at all. Keep yourself busy, keep bannermen around you. And I’ll be very carefuly that he doesn’t catch me alone either.”

Her eyes glinted with amusement.

“Maybe it was a good idea, that you brought this here. I’m sure we can spread the word, that people have to keep us busy.”

Jon smiled. The scheme did appeal to him, but it would mean less time alone with Sansa. Not that they had had much of this lately. I guess, if I want some time alone, I have to catch nits again.

“I still would like to have an edge. I don’t trust this Harold already. If you read Robin’s letter right, he might be very dangerous in his ambition.”

Jon let his eyes wander around the room, fully taking in the persons in the room for the first time.

His gaze went back to Lady Alys. He narrowed his eyes. The Gods told me that she is like my sister. I should trust her.

“Lady Alys, there is a great opportunity to prove your loyalty” he addressed her.

Alys looked up, her face curious in a way that did remind him of his sister Arya and shortly made his heart ache.

“You know how to fight, but you have not yet a reputation like Lady Brienne has.” Alys made a face as if she had an idea what Jon was about to ask.

“Have you written to Robin about Alys?” Jon asked Sansa. She shook her head.

“You could be the new court lady of Lady Sansa, dagger hidden in your dress, just in case. It would comfort me to know that somebody is around Lady Sansa, in case this Harold forgets himself.”

Alys’ face fell. “A dress?”, she exclaimed, misery plain on her face.

Jon grinned. “A dress. You would only need to do this for as long as this Harold Hardyng is here.” He couldn’t help himself. His voice already betrayed his dislike for a man he had never met.

“Jon,” Sansa interrupted him. “You cannot possibly order Lady Alys to do that. It’s clear she doesn’t like dresses.”

Alys turned her face to Sansa.

“I’ll do it,” she said. “I’ll wear bloody dresses and prevent that man to get you alone.”

That took Sansa by surprise, Jon could see that.

“Only under one condition, though,” Alys added.

“Which would be?”, Sansa asked.

Alys gave her a mischievous grin that made her look like a younger girl.

“If these men from the Vale bring nits and lice to Winterfell again I want you to allow me to dump them from the castle battlements and drive them out of Winterfell.”

“I’ll do the dumping with you.”
trail.content:
Another chapter of my slowburn…. Mostly setting up for the next greater arc. The vale might look like a diversion, but it is necessary for a latter plot point…. Also on AO3.

 “Dear Sansa, I hope this letter finds you and your children well. I have written several times already, but with the whole of Westeros in the grip of Winter, the ravens might not have reached you. The latest message I received from you was the news about the Riverlands. I was glad to hear that Hoster Tully has reached Winterfell. I am convinced that you will be an excellent warden for him. I suspect that you have written since, but no raven reached us here in the Vale.

My health has not been the best of late, although I try to keep quiet about it. The medicine I take is highly recommended by my new Maester Rhyswont, so I still have hope that my health improves. My old Maester Colemon has died of a sudden fever and my conditions has worsened since that. With the war in the South decided for Daenerys, my knights worry that we will have to face another threat from the South soon. Harold Hardyng, my beloved and trusted heir, is sceptical about your need for our knights. Even though several men have told him about the abominations they met north of the Wall, he refuses to believe. Therefore, I send him to Winterfell together with Maester Rhyswont, who is also a sceptic. I want him to judge the situation on his own. If anything happens to me I want my heir to honour our alliance. This is the fourth message I’ve sent to you and it might be, that by the time it reaches you, Harold is already close to Winterfell. Robin Arryn, Warden of the East.”

Jon read it out loud. When he had received the letter his first thought was that Sansa would help him steering through the troubled waters. Jon had the feeling that there was more to this letter than met the eye. Sansa knew her cousin. It was only when he had finished reading out the letter loudly and asked Sansa what it all meant that he realised that Sansa shook her head in an almost inperceptible way.

“We’d better discuss this in the council,” Sansa said at the same time as Gilly exclaimed loudly: “Maester Rhyswont!”

Jon was distracted by Gilly’s face which was a grimace of distaste.

“What about Maester Rhyswont?” he asked.

Gilly combed Podrick’s hair with determination which earned her a high-pitched yelp, when the comb did not run through his hair smoothly.

“Maester Rhyswont is a very good maester, but he treats women like they are all dumbwits. He was one of the few who would protest against me sitting quietly in the back of the classes to listen.” Gilly grumbled.

“He is a good healer though.”, she admitted. “He left shortly before we made our way North.”.

“If he is a good healer why does Lord Robin send him North though?”, Sansa mused, voicing one of the oddities of the letter. There was a frown on her forehead.

“And who sent the raven from the Vale, if he was already on his way here?” Jon asked.

“Robin might have someone at hand who is capable to tend the ravens.” Sansa stretched out her hand and Jon handed her the letter.

“This letter is from Robin,” she confirmed, fingering Robin’s signature.

“What do you make of it?” Jon wanted to know.

Sansa sighed. “We really should discuss this in council,” she chided him, but relented when she saw his face. His anxiousness which had nothing to do with Maester Rhyswont or Lord Robin’s health must have been visible on his face.

“It is odd, that Robin mentions the new medicine. I would say, that he suspects that it is not good for his health at all and he wants the Maester away to test this.” Sansa looked at the nitcomb absentmindedly.

“I do not like this,” she admitted. “He calls this Harold his ‘beleoved and trusted’ heir. Why trust him, if he is sceptic about the White Walkers and the conditions of our alliance.”

The alliance. The alliance he wants honoured. Jon felt a cold fear clutch at his heart. He knew how alliances were forged and he did not like it. Not at all. Harold comes as a suitor for Sansa’s hand. He looked down at his hand that shook with anger at the thought and tried to get his temper in hand. Sansa will not leave Winterfell, she’ll stay here with me. He wished he could feel secure about this. What will she do, if this Harold sets conditions for the troops from the Vale. What if Robin dies? Jon had never met Sansa’s cousin and Sansa had told him that the sickly Robin was not easy to deal with, but he was fond of his cousin and Jon knew that it was only due to this fondness that Robin had refrained from revenging Littlefinger’s death. He had been a good ally over three years, and the Vale had bled in the continuous war against the Walkers like the North had.

Sansa seemed to feel Jon’s eyes on her and tried a reassuring smile.

“I do think he wants us to assess this Maester Rhyswont and his heir. It is a prudent move. Let the sceptic learn something about our war, remove the Maester in case he is behind his worsened health, and remove his heir who might be overly ambitions. If I read this letter right, Robin had to appease a hostile fraction at his court.” She paused.

“It also means he trust us to convince that fraction and help him.” She looked at the comb in her hands again and then raised her face to him. Her blue eyes met his.

“Apparently he did learn some things while he was Littlefinger’s ward”, Jon tried to distract some of the tension with a joke.

The corner of Sansa’s mouth only quirked lightly.

“So many ravens lost worries me,” Sansa said. “I’ve written twice while you were at the wall. It could be an accident of course.”

She concentrated on her comb again. She’s avoiding looking at me. Jon’s heart felt like a lump in his chest. He had hoped that he was mistaken about the message of the last sentence.

There was an uncomfortable silence. Jon could feel the blood rushing in his ears. I should not have come, I should have waited.

“We should decide on what our answer will be, if that Harold wants to marry me.” Sansa said in an almost whisper. She looked up again and this time she held Jon’s gaze.

His heart made an odd jump. Our answer. He felt as if Sansa and he were the only people in the room. He did not see any of the others in the room, just Sansa.

“We cannot outright deny him,” Jon answered. “Not before he has pledged to fight with us against the Walkers.” I could always just chop off his head. That dark thought came unbidden and Jon shuddered involuntarily.

“No, but we can detain him. It might mean that you’ll have to go to the Wall again to show him proof.”

Jon felt blood rush in his face. It filled him with grim satisfaction that there was no question for Sansa, that she would not want to marry this Harold, but he also realised that he might have given away some of his feelings to others. Again. I must be more careful.

“I would like to avoid that. With the gods staying silent, I feel there is great danger here in Winterfell. ‘Stay alert’ they said. No order about going North.” ‘Stay alert. Stay steadfast’. Jon did not want to leave again.

“Yes, that is worrying. I really wish they had been clearer about that.” Sansa agreed.

Suddenly she laughed.

“The best way to detain him would probably be to avoid that he even asks the question,” she finally said, when she had contained her mirth.

“You just have to pretend that you don’t understand his question at all. Keep yourself busy, keep bannermen around you. And I’ll be very carefuly that he doesn’t catch me alone either.”

Her eyes glinted with amusement.

“Maybe it was a good idea, that you brought this here. I’m sure we can spread the word, that people have to keep us busy.”

Jon smiled. The scheme did appeal to him, but it would mean less time alone with Sansa. Not that they had had much of this lately. I guess, if I want some time alone, I have to catch nits again.

“I still would like to have an edge. I don’t trust this Harold already. If you read Robin’s letter right, he might be very dangerous in his ambition.”

Jon let his eyes wander around the room, fully taking in the persons in the room for the first time.

His gaze went back to Lady Alys. He narrowed his eyes. The Gods told me that she is like my sister. I should trust her.

“Lady Alys, there is a great opportunity to prove your loyalty” he addressed her.

“You could be the new court lady of Lady Sansa, dagger hidden in your dress, just in case. It would comfort me to know that somebody is around Lady Sansa, in case this Harold forgets himself.”

Alys’ face fell. “A dress?”, she exclaimed, misery plain on her face.

Jon grinned. “A dress. You would only need to do this for as long as this Harold Hardyng is here.” He couldn’t help himself. His voice already betrayed his dislike for a man he had never met.

“Jon,” Sansa interrupted him. “You cannot possibly order Lady Alys to do that. It’s clear she doesn’t like dresses.”

Alys turned her face to Sansa.

“I’ll do it,” she said. “I’ll wear bloody dresses and prevent that man to get you alone.”

That took Sansa by surprise, Jon could see that.

“Only under one condition, though,” Alys added.

“Which would be?”, Sansa asked.

Alys gave her a mischievous grin that made her look like a younger girl.

“If these men from the Vale bring nits and lice to Winterfell again I want you to allow me to dump them from the castle battlements and drive them out of Winterfell.”

“I’ll do the dumping with you.”

The latest message I received from you was the news about the Riverlands. I was glad to hear that Hoster Tully has reached Winterfell. I am convinced that you will be an excellent warden for him. summary: character quotes: the sansa storyline I most certainly have not forgotten that little she-wolf. I ought to have shown her to the...
caption:
character quotes: the sansa storyline

I most certainly have not forgotten that little she-wolf. I ought to have shown her to the black cells as the daughter of a traitor, but instead I made her part of mine own household. She shared my hearth and hall, played with my own children. I fed her, dressed her, tried to make her a little less ignorant about the world, and how did she repay me for my kindness? She helped murder my son. When we find the Imp, we will find the Lady Sansa too. She is not dead … but before I am done with her, I promise you, she will be singing to the Stranger, begging for his kiss. - C.LANNISTER
